497.question: Is CRWIZ already used for data collection, what are the results?

7-Table3-1.png: Yes, CRWIZ was used for data collection. The results show that the distribution of dialogue acts in the data collected with CRWIZ is similar to the distribution of dialogue acts in the data collected with Lopes et al. (2019).
7-Table2-1.png: Yes, the CRWIZ tool was used for data collection. The results of the Wizard-of-Oz experiment in a controlled setting were compared with the interaction features of the dialogues collected.
6-Figure4-1.png: Yes, CRWIZ is already used for data collection. The results show that there were 40 unique dialogue acts, each with two or more distinct formulations on average. Most of them also had slots to fill with contextual information, such as the name of the robot. The dialogue acts are color-coded based on three main types.
9-Table5-1.png: Yes, CRWIZ is already used for data collection. The results show that the participants are actively engaged in the dialogue and are discussing various topics related to the project.
8-Table4-1.png: Yes, CRWIZ was used for data collection. The results show that the majority of the collected dialogues were not resolved, while a smaller portion were resolved. The data also shows that the median and mode of the collected dialogues were lower than the standard deviation, indicating that the dialogues were generally of lower quality.
6-Figure5-1.png: The image shows a graph with a color-coded scale, indicating the frequency of various dialogue acts in the Emergency Assistant system. The top-10 dialogue acts are displayed, with the most common act being "ack okay." The results suggest that the system is being utilized effectively, as the most common dialogue act is "ack okay," which indicates that the system is being used to communicate with users.

497.answer: Yes, CRWIZ has been used for data collection and its initial use resulted in 145 dialogues. The average time taken for the task was close to the estimate of 10 minutes, 14 dialogues (9.66%) resolved the emergency in the scenario, and these dialogues rated consistently higher in subjective and objective ratings than those which did not resolve the emergency. Qualitative results showed that participants believed that they were interacting with an automated assistant.
